data.title: Chord Energy: This U.S. Oil Gem's Valuation Disconnect Is Too Big To Ignore
data.description:
Introduction

The last time I covered Chord Energy (CHRD), I highlighted their robust cash flow, significant efficiencies, improvements, and healthy balance sheet, reiterating their Strong Buy rating.

I reiterate CHRD’s Strong Buy rating following the solid earnings report, as the company remains one of the best opportunities in US oil today, in my opinion, maintaining a strong balance sheet with no maturities until 2030 and significant potential to develop as a strong Williston Basin producer.

Internal Developments

Chord reported what I would call a strong Q4 and 2025 overall given the macro conditions, beating the market’s non-GAAP EPS and revenue estimates, with $692.72 million in FCF in 2025 (compared to $918.15 million in 2024).

As for the guidance, Chord expects about $1.4 billion worth of CAPEX (at midpoint) in 2026 - $50 million higher than 2025 at midpoint - and roughly $700 million in FCF once again when using benchmark prices of $64 per barrel of oil and $3.75 per MMBtu of natural gas, placing them at an attractive P/FCF ratio of about 8.43 today despite the current macro pressures.

As a result of all the recent acquisitions, lateral expansions and efficiency enhancements (~$160 million in annual run-rate savings, or roughly 23% of the FCF expected in 2026), Chord became a very strong Williston Basin producer (largest acreage holder and producer there), as even though they aren’t operating in the best basin, they’re still delivering very solid per share improvements despite the ongoing macro pressure, and I believe the market is still sleeping on it given the valuation, for now, while the CEO highlighted the following during their Q4 Earnings Call:

As we look forward to 2026, Chord's plan builds upon last year's success and remains focused on optimizing capital allocation, generating strong returns and improving continuously. Last year, Chord set a goal of converting 80% of its inventory to long laterals. I'm happy to report that we achieved that goal by year-end 2025, which was earlier than expected, and is a testament to the hard work and dedication of our team.

Financially, based on CHRD’s latest report, we see a strong balance sheet, with a net leverage of ~0.6x as of the latest report, and also no maturities until all the way in 2030 (and 2033), which I believe leaves significant room for more debt if they want to ramp up their expansion through another big acquisition or other developments.

Regarding Chord’s capital returns, I remain a big fan of their balanced approach, with the company prioritizing their balance sheet and leverage over returns, targeting 75%+ of adjusted FCF while the leverage is below 0.5x, 50%+ while the leverage is below 1x (nowadays), or just the base dividend plus potential for other returns when the leverage is above 1x.

As a note, their selected peers currently stand at a leverage of 1.1x, while the SPDR S&P Oil & Gas Expl & Prod ETF (XOP) is at 1.7x, so the fact that they are well below that and are still taking a very careful approach remains yet another factor that highlights their quality, in my opinion.

For the Q4 performance, CHRD has recently declared a $1.30/share quarterly dividend (the base), which places them at a roughly 5% yield today, representing roughly $295 million per year, alongside $10 million in buybacks for the quarter, for a very solid ~48% payout ratio, in line with the target. However, if we assume an improvement in leverage and a 75% payout ratio on the $700 million FCF they expect in 2026, we’re talking about $525 million in total, meaning a yield of roughly 9%, which is not bad at all in such an environment.

Macro Developments

To update a key development started in the previous analysis, I want to begin this segment by quickly mentioning the situation in Venezuela. Under the current conditions, I believe Exxon (XOM) characterized Venezuela’s oil landscape very well when they called it “uninvestable,” as we should keep in mind that it’s true that the country’s oil reserves are massive, but any operations there will require massive investments.

After all, we’re not only talking about one of the heaviest oils on the planet (lots of refining needed), but the infrastructure there is very old, likely the remnants of what American companies left there before they were nationalized (in 1976), with some upgrades made over time. In this oil environment, it’s very hard to find the funds (CAPEX-cutting environment) and the risk appetite to develop something in the country.

Sure, things can improve in the long term and the country is working on an overhaul of their oil industry after Maduro was removed, but nothing guarantees that these operations won’t be taken again or economic conditions won’t change. After all, Trump’s term is over in about 3 years, and we can never know who comes to power next (in either country) and potentially cut the US’ grip that’s just now being developed.

However, there are several other uncertain factors that the market will pay attention to. If things were that simple, then this wouldn’t have been one of the most volatile commodities on the planet, after all. For example, although OPEC+ continued to go for their previously planned halt in production hikes shortly after the Maduro operation, that’s providing some clarity only until the end of Q1, and a switch here can cause pressure on the price of oil once again.

In fact, very recent reports indicate that OPEC+ may decide to raise oil output by 137,000 bpd starting in April 2026 in order to meet peak summer demand, which can be only the beginning of more near-term pressure on the price.

Meanwhile, the situation in Iran is also developing, while the war in Ukraine is taking steps towards an eventual end, which can even lead to somewhat of the opposite of the price jumps, disruptions, and sanctions that came afterward.

Regardless, even before the current situation, we saw J.P. Morgan’s warning saying that we could even see oil drop into the $30s by 2027 in a massive oversupply scenario, which could be terrible for a company like CHRD, as the Williston Basin inventory acquired recently, for example, has a breakeven in the $40s. Indeed, they are improving through acquisitions and the lateral expansion, and this breakeven is a significant upgrade compared to their bankrupt parents, but they would still face issues here.

However, the same J.P. Morgan also has more “normal” outlooks that seem to be in line with OPEC’s halt, estimating Brent prices of $58 and WTI at $54 in 2026, followed by $57 and $53 in 2027, respectively, which still makes CHRD very profitable.

Risks Reiterated

Ultimately, CHRD remains tied to the prices of their commodities, and if we see oil drop to the mid-to-high $50s as JPM expects, we are talking about quite a big drop for CHRD's FCF, as the company's breakeven costs lead to massive swings at these levels, with their FCF yield being estimated at 5% with WTI prices at $55, 16% at $70, and 25% at $85.

This also means that volatility is something we should assume from the start, as the commodity will depend a lot on politics, speculation, outlooks, news, etc., which can lead to rapid swings in near-term valuations.

Valuation

For CHRD’s DCF to Equity valuation, starting from their expected $700 million in FCF in 2026 (assuming average prices of $64 WTI and $3.75 HH for the entire period) without accounting for any change in net borrowings since I want to highlight their “pure” potential.

As a result of the mix of synergies, laterals expansion, and other savings that they're delivering, I'll assume that the CAPEX remains flat at $700 million in 2027 as well, followed by a jump to $1.20 billion in 2028 as the CAPEX could drop and they should be able to reap the benefits of their investments, followed by a CAGR of 3.5% until 2035 and a 2.5% terminal growth rate, with a relatively high discount rate of 12.5% to take into account their basin exposure risks and volatility, with 56.84 million shares outstanding as of their Q4 report.

This way, we get to an equity value of $11.12 billion, for an intrinsic value of $195.68 per share, which is significantly above the current $105.38.

However, I’ll also try to gauge the current market estimates, just to get an idea about the difference between CHRD’s potential and the current valuation. If we start with their $700 million FCF in 2026 and, instead of the previous jump, assume a 4% CAGR until 2030, a 3% CAGR until 2035, and a 2.25% terminal growth rate, with a 15% discount rate and 56.84 million shares outstanding.

This gets us to an intrinsic value of $103.39, which almost perfectly mirrors the current level, taking into account a massive discount rate and weak growth despite the company’s achievements, which I don’t consider correct.

Conclusions

CHRD remains a Strong Buy, being in a very solid financial position, with prudent management that’s been delivering great improvements in recent years and a solid yield on top.

There are risks to keep in mind, as their breakeven costs are still elevated given the basin exposure, but the company is advancing rapidly in a very good direction, transforming significantly since it was formed, which I believe should warrant better valuations going forward.

As a final note, especially given the continued M&A activity seen in the market, I wouldn’t be surprised to see another peer try to acquire CHRD given the valuation, quality, and size.

data.title: Politics And The Markets 02/28/26
data.description:
This is the forum for daily political discussion on Seeking Alpha. A new version is published every market day.

Please don't leave political comments on other articles or posts on the site.

The comments below are not regulated with the same rigor as the rest of the site, and this is an 'enter at your own risk' area as discussion can get very heated. If you can't stand the heat... you know what they say...

More on Today's Markets:

Moderation Guidelines:

We remove comments under the following categories:

  • Personal attacks on another user account
  • Anti-Vaxxer or covid related misinformation
  • Stereotyping, prejudiced or racist language about individuals or the topic under discussion.
  • Inciting violence messages, encouraging hate groups and political violence.

Regardless of which side of the political divide you find yourself, please be courteous and don't direct abuse at other users.

For any issue with regards to comments please email us at : moderation@seekingalpha.com.

Seeking Alpha's Disclosure: Past performance is no guarantee of future results. No recommendation or advice is being given as to whether any investment is suitable for a particular investor. Any views or opinions expressed above may not reflect those of Seeking Alpha as a whole. Seeking Alpha is not a licensed securities dealer, broker or US investment adviser or investment bank. Our analysts are third party authors that include both professional investors and individual investors who may not be licensed or certified by any institute or regulatory body.

data.title: METL: Active Diversified Metals Miners, Up 50% Since Inception In The Past Year
data.description:
Thesis

The parabolic move up in precious metals is known to the entire investing public; however, fewer investors know that mining companies geared towards those commodities have also rallied hard. The market has been focused in the past year on gold miners, while other segments of the investing universe should also have taken some bandwidth. In today's article we are going to explore a fairly new ETF, namely the Sprott Active Metals & Miners ETF (METL). The fund came to market in September 2025 and has soared over +50% since inception.

First the metals soared, then the miners

The geopolitical landscape has been marked by the conflict in Ukraine for the past few years, a conflict that has made central banks around the world aware of the power of sanctions. After the 2022 invasion, Russia's reserves abroad were frozen.

After Russia’s full-scale invasion, the U.S. and its allies froze Russian foreign exchange reserves in their jurisdictions. The Russian Elites, Proxies, and Oligarchs (REPO) Task Force—consisting of the Group of Seven (G7), European Union (EU), and Australia—most recently estimated frozen reserves at $280 billion. Many experts (and the Central Bank of Russia) put the figure between $300 and $330 billion.

This move has made it clear to many foreign countries that dollar- and euro-denominated assets can have the same fate in the case of a conflict. The result? An accelerated move away from treasuries and euro bonds and into precious metals:

As per the chart above, courtesy of Bloomberg, central banks across the world now hold more gold than treasuries.

The net impact on precious metals is fairly easy to see:

While gold and silver were the main beneficiaries, please note the rally in platinum and copper as well. When precious metal prices rally and stay high for a while, it translates into higher profits for the mining companies pulling the metals from the core of the earth. The correlation is not immediate since high gold prices for a short period of time do not translate into solid forward profitability for gold miners. However, when prices stay elevated for a while, miners tend to follow. And they have.

What does METL do?

Let us start with the fund objective for METL:

An actively managed ETF that aims to provide long-term capital appreciation by investing in companies across the metals and mining industry lifecycle, including miners, recyclers, and royalty and streaming companies associated with commodities that are in high global demand. The Fund’s investment strategy is value-oriented and contrarian.

The ETF is therefore an active one that aims to invest in equities of companies involved in the metals and mining lifecycle. Currently the fund composition is as follows:

Copper equities make up the largest proportion of the fund at 29.2%, followed by silver equities at 19.8% and uranium equities at 18%. Please note the allocation to rare earth equities and lithium equities as well. Most of these companies are either large cap or mid cap:

Large and mid caps make up over 76% of the fund holdings, thus leaving small capitalization equities at sub-25%. The largest exposures as of the latest fact sheet are as follows:

Some of the names in the above list are staples of the Global X Silver Miners ETF (SIL). An investor can find the SIL holdings here. Wheaton Precious Metals has a very large representation in SIL but only 3.17% in METL.

METL is much more diversified and allocates capital to copper and rare earth miners and lifecycle companies as opposed to single-segment choices. Note that gold miners are virtually not represented currently, but keep in mind this ETF is active and thus can choose to change holdings as valuations make sense.

Performance

The fund is very new, but we can have a look at how it has done versus some other names in the space:

Since its inception, METL has put in a performance very much in line with the VanEck Gold Miners ETF (GDX) and has underperformed the silver focused SIL. METL is more focused currently on the metal equities next in line for substantial rallies, namely copper and rare earths. We view the fund as a great allocator to the metals space, especially when considering higher prices for longer.

The fund portfolio managers have the flexibility to invest in equities associated with a wide range of metals thus can provide exposure to specific metals potentially positioned for outperformance based on market macro conditions and intrinsic valuation metrics.

Some analytics around this ETF are as follows:

  • AUM: $112 M
  • Expense ratio: 0.89%

The fund does not have enough historical data to generate reliable risk analytics, but given the performance correlation with SIL and GDX, one can safely assume very similar risk statistics for now. METL will be able to generate better analytics long term due to its active management, so we are excited to see the name outperform as we move forward.

Conclusion

METL is a new ETF from Sprott, focused on metals miners across the spectrum. The fund is active and thus can change its composition as it sees fit. The ETF is currently overweight copper and silver miners, with almost no gold miners present in the holdings. The fund has done very well since its recent inception (September 2025), being up over +50%. The name represents a great portfolio diversifier for individuals believing higher metal prices are here to stay for longer.

data.title: Markets Weekly Outlook: Credit Crunch Fears To Conclude A Temperamental Month; NFP Incoming
data.description:
By Elior Manier

Week in review: Markets remain very anxious, and they just found a new reason

It seems traders will have to keep looking for reasons for volatility, as things won't settle anytime soon. Since Kevin Warsh's nomination to head the Federal Reserve, markets have been raging in brutal up-and-down swings.

Despite the harsh narratives, stock benchmarks remain near their all-time highs, and the immediate action looks more like a widespread rebalancing than a full-blown risk dump.

The most speculative assets have been slowly being tossed out since the October risk peaks, and this move is quickly translating into a newfound interest in quality (albeit not yet a real migration).

As some analysts call for a transition to the peak of the economic cycle, defensive assets and sectors are attracting attention. Bonds and metals are actually the best performers this week.

After cryptocurrencies, tech/software, and semiconductors, a more concerning wave is gripping financial markets. Waves of defaults among private equity and some of the most shaky tech companies are dragging down private lenders, venture capital firms, and some financials.

In case you forgot, this comes promptly after credit spreads reached new 2007 lows, and within not even a month, they are coming back to their December highs.

What could be concerning is how highly correlated the financial system has become since the Great Financial Crisis. Banks grew enormously, and it seems people quickly turned the page on the 2023 SVB blow-up, which raised questions about how large a credit spiderweb it has become.

In any case, the monthly picture is a scary one for financials, and that's getting even more amplified today. Bank of America (BAC) is down close to 4%, Goldman Sachs (GS) and Morgan Stanley (MS) are closer to -8%, but that's only the major banks.

Smaller lenders like Blackstone (BX), Jefferies (JEF), and KKR & Co. (KKR) are down close to 30% on the month, and even Robinhood (HOOD) is suffering similar-sized drops. UBS is sending their own warnings, and they're not pretty.

This will surely maintain more anxiety in the markets. It's not that AI will lead to immediate spikes in layoffs; it's more about what happens to those who get replaced and how it spreads through the financial system at this point.

Weekly Performance across Asset Classes

Silver is calling and it wants its crown back! The precious metal is closing well above its early February monthly highs as metals caught a strong bid in today's action. These are preparations for something happening over the weekend.

The Week Ahead: NFP and PMIs all around the globe

Asia Pacific Markets: A condensed data package for APAC

Next week should be exciting for APAC traders. Without counting geopolitics, macro traders will await three PMI reports for China. There has been a surprising drop in the data as of late, and the PBoC is talking about supporting their economy, not through market-wide stimulus but with targeted assistance. It will be interesting to see how it plays out in the data.

The Australian dollar will once again be on the front scene, between inflation surveys, a speech from Governor Bullock, PMIs, trade data and GDP. It's going to be a very essential week for the 2026 FX leader. Let's see if it holds up to the test.

In Japan, traders will be listening closely to Governor Ueda's speech on Monday night. A hike could be coming towards mid-month for the Bank of Japan, and he upped his tone recently regarding the possibility.

With two new decision-makers entering the Bank of Japan in the next months, it could be his last opportunity to build some form of consensus.

Europe and UK Markets: Eurozone and Swiss Inflation

The heavy slate of data also spreads to Europe with inflation data (consumer prices and producer prices) releasing. Friday will also see the yearly data for EU GDP, so keep this one in check.

But the largest culprit will be the Swiss inflation report, where traders should confirm whether negative rates will be a thing or not. A heavy test for FX markets.

North American Markets: More PMIs, but most importantly, non farm payrolls

Next week is going to be huge for North America. Without mentioning Iran, traders will receive a streak of PMIs from Canada and the US. A first round will come on Monday (manufacturing), and the second will be on Wednesday (services), along with the Beige Book (which had been a no-show but is slowly getting interesting).

But markets will have to wait for the real parade: Friday will release a retail sales and non-farm payrolls double-decker at 8:30 A.M. Retail sales sent an honest shocker last month, missing by 0.5 percentage points, while non-farm payrolls remained surprisingly strong. Make sure to not miss our incoming previews.

Now, with a finally timely NFP, participants shall see if this boost in employment really proves to be solid or just a seasonal one (with new year employment).

Even after the latest ease in narrative, keep a close eye on geopolitical developments, particularly those involving the US-Iran talks, as they are likely to continue influencing commodity and broader markets.

Next Week's High-Tier Economic Events

For all market-moving economic releases and events, see the MarketPulse Economic Calendar. (High-tier data only)

Friday 27's Market Wrap

Today's session really continued the past session's turn towards geopolitical hedges and a general turn towards quality. As mentioned in the introduction, banks have seen bloodshed along with tech companies, and this comes right after the gigantic Nvidia earnings.

A very concerning picture of what's coming. Still, stock markets are closing off of their session lows, supported by calmer month-end flows in the afternoon.

The US dollar is also surprisingly at the bottom of the FX board, a victim of some heavy repositioning or month-end settling flows.The CHF leading isn't very surprising, however. Expect to hear about Iran this weekend. Stay safe, everyone!

Safe trades, and enjoy your weekend!

Original Post

Editor's Note: The summary bullets for this article were chosen by Seeking Alpha editors.

data.title: SPYD: Momentum Is Now On The High-Yield Factor's Side (Rating Upgrade)
data.description:
Dispersion and diversification have been the market’s passwords ever since the Information Technology sector and Magnificent Seven stocks peaked back in October 2025. Indeed, the State Street SPDR Portfolio S&P 500 High Dividend ETF (SPYD) has been a notable outperformer, as areas like Real Estate and Consumer Staples have posted big alpha.

But it hasn’t been a clear path higher since last April. I had a hold rating on SPYD shortly after Liberation Day. The fund is up 33%, dividends included, but that lags the S&P 500 by about six percentage points. What’s more, SPYD was little changed from my previous assessment to mid-November. It's only been in the last few months that investors have taken a shine to the blue-chip dividend yield factor.

Today, with both a solid valuation and relative strength, I am upgrading SPYD to a buy. I’ll detail the valuation, the holdings, and the chart—all of those factors suggest more upside is to come in 2026.

SYPD Lagged Badly Through October, But Has Gained Major Traction Into 2026

High-Dividend Yield Factor Outperforming

According to the issuer, SPYD seeks to track the performance of the S&P 500 High Dividend Index. It offers a low-cost option to investors seeking both dividend income and potential capital growth. The ETF focuses on the top 80 high-dividend-yielding companies within the S&P 500 Index. SPYD can serve as a core fund for building a diversified portfolio across asset classes.

SPYD is a medium-sized ETF, now with $7.6 billion in assets under management as of February 25, 2026. That’s up from just $6.5 billion at the time of my previous analysis. The annual expense ratio is low at only 7 basis points, while the trailing 12-month dividend yield is high at 4.11%, about 2.9 percentage points above that of the S&P 500.

Share-price momentum has improved markedly just in the last handful of months, now earning the product a B- ETF Grade in that category by Seeking Alpha’s quantitative scoring system (it was a D- back in November). From a risk perspective, SPYD scores decently, but high exposure to cyclical and defensive sectors can bring about a unique set of risks, namely steep negative alpha when the Mag 7 take off.

For now, liquidity is quite strong. Average daily volume is north of 1.8 million shares, while the median 30-day bid/ask spread is very tight at just two basis points, per State Street Funds.

For an update on the portfolio, the 2-star, Gold-rated ETF by Morningstar plots (not surprisingly) on the far-left side of the style box, indicating its weight toward the value style. There is no growth access, while more than 80% of the allocation is classified as SMID-cap by Morningstar.

While the fund is largely unexposed to some of today’s biggest AI risks (as seen in the software industry), macroeconomic factors play a large role in price action. Interest rates are particularly key. In general, the lower Treasury yields go, the more attractive high-yield equities become.

On valuation, SPYD’s price-to-earnings ratio is very compelling at 13.7x, but the long-term earnings growth rate is also modest, near 6%. I would not be surprised to see EPS estimates get taken higher, as broader profit growth cascades across the so-called “real” economy.

SPYD: Portfolio & Factor Profiles

Zooming in on the sector breakdown, Real Estate is by far the largest stake. I consider Real Estate to be like the last frontier of the diversification trade. The property slice of the S&P 500 is right near 52-week highs as its leadership emerges.

Much has also been made of how strong Consumer Staples has been—it, too, is a marked overweight. Financials is close to market weight, and it has lagged badly this year. If banks can regain their footing, that is a notable upside catalyst for SPYD.

And with the ETF’s modified-equal-weight structure, no single stock commands a large position. So, there is diversification from that perspective.

SPYD: Holdings & Dividend Information

With a low P/E and much better price action, SPYD’s seasonality is not ideal today. March has occasionally featured increased volatility, while modest gains have occurred, on average, in April and May. Keep in mind that the below view is for price-only returns (dividends are not included).

SPYD: Muted Seasonal Trends

The Technical Take

Given the solid valuation and impressive relative strength, SPYD’s technicals check out well. Notice in the chart below that the fund is right near all-time highs. It scaled the November 2024 previous high-water mark after surging from November through the turn of this year. Now, with a rising long-term 200-day moving average, the bulls clearly control the primary trend. Price is above the 50 dma, which is higher than the 200 dma.

Also take a look at the volume by price profile on the left side of the graph. There should be major support if we see a pullback. For now, support is right near the current price, with a firmer layer between $45 and $45. I expect the current bull flag pattern to resolve higher, and it makes sense that the ETF is working off technical overbought conditions (as evidenced by the RSI momentum oscillator at the top of the chart).

In terms of an upside target, a measured move objective to $67 is in play based on the depth of the Q4 2024 to April 2025 decline and subsequent breakout.

SPYD: Bullish Upside Breakout, Bull Flag, Rising 200dma

The Bottom Line

I have a buy rating on SPYD. I see much-improved momentum, relative strength, and technicals. Fundamentally, the valuation is very low, while the high-dividend yield factor has grabbed leadership in today’s more-diversified market.

data.title: Dividend Champion, Contender, And Challenger Highlights: Week Of March 1
data.description:
Introduction

The Dividend Champions list is a monthly compilation of companies that have consistently increased their annual dividend payouts. However, since this list is only produced once per month, the data in it can quickly get out of date. Furthermore, with around 700 companies on the list, the sheer amount of data can quickly become overwhelming. In this weekly series, I highlight recent and upcoming dividend-related activity for dividend stocks on the Dividend Champions list.

In the data presented below, Yield is forward annualized, and Years reflects the up-to-date streak, including dividends declared since the last edition of the Dividend Champions list.

data.title: Dow Jones And U.S. Index Outlook: U.S. Stocks Rebound After Gap Down; Month-End Flows Incoming
data.description:
By Elior Manier

Another crazy month for markets is ending today, and investors are sighing after an impressive gap lower. The reasoning behind the risk-off flows was that US embassies in the Middle East had called for their staff to prepare security measures over the weekend, leading to a spike in oil to $68 and a rough pre-open session.

Dow Jones was leading indexes lower, dipping to -1.78% before rebounding. Benchmarks are now attempting to erase the entire overnight drop; however, this may prove difficult as traders prepare for a volatile session close, pulled on both sides by weekend risk and month-end flow volatility.

The rebound is strong, with recent Chicago PMI data (57.7 vs 52.8 exp) confirming that US data is far from weakening; quite the opposite, in fact. Produce prices have risen to 8-month highs amid elevated activity, further pressuring prices. This could prevent further rate cuts and hurt sentiment in the near term.

This will prove challenging for risk sentiment, but looking at the immediate action, bulls and bears are just fighting within a range.

Let's look at the technical situation by diving into today's session charts and key trading levels for the major US indices: the Dow Jones, Nasdaq, and S&P 500.

Current Session's Stock Heatmap

While the Dow struggled the most during overnight futures trading, defensive stocks are taking the lead again against the tech and financial sectors, seeing a second consecutive day of outflows.

Nvidia (NVDA) is leading to the downside along with JPMorgan (JPM), as investors keep punishing the record numbers and projections and rotating back to the more traditional, HALO stocks.

It seems that participants are agreeing that we are slowly shifting towards the late cycle in the most powerful economy.

Dow Jones 2H Chart and Trading Levels

The DJIA is crossing back below the 49,000 psychological level. With all due respect to the volatility of recent action, this recent price action really just resembles another establishment of a 1,000-point range within the index - holding between 48,600 and 49,600.

The immediate action is a doji, so hesitancy will contain the action until either bulls or bears take the hand:

  • Watch for a break above 49,041 for more upside
  • For more downside, watch for a move below 48,750
  • Keep a close eye on the formation of a short-timeframe bear channel

Dow Jones technical levels for trading:

Resistance Levels

  • Intraday channel highs and 2H 50-period MA: 49,200
  • January ATH resistance 49,500 to 49,700 (rejection)
  • Past session highs: 49,850
  • 49,900 to 50,000 resistance (range highs)
  • Index all-time highs: 50,512

Support Levels

  • Session lows and past week support: 48,660 to 48,750 (bearish below)
  • November ATH 48,300 to 48,500 minor support
  • Key support from 47,500 to 48,000 (next main support)
  • 45,000 psychological level (main support on higher timeframe)

Nasdaq 2H Chart and Trading Levels

Nasdaq is looking confused again - and if confusion doesn't inspire you, it could always be safe to look elsewhere. A short-term, strange-looking double bottom hints at a short-term bounce.

However, the 2H 50-period MA will be acting as immediate resistance. Failing to breach it could lead to further downside (watch the 24,740 intraday support)

Nasdaq technical levels of interest:

Resistance Levels

  • 25,000 pivot level and 2H 50-period MA
  • 25,400 to 25,500 key intraday resistance
  • All-time high resistance zone 26,100 to 26,300

Support Levels

  • Mini intraday support 24,744 (bearish below)
  • 24,500 to 25,600 key support (range support)
  • February support: 24,150 to 24,200
  • October-November support: 23,800 to 24,000
  • Early 2025 ATH at 22,000 to 22,229 support

S&P 500 2H Chart and Trading Levels

The S&P 500 also looks quite mixed, which points at similar breakout potentials as the Dow Jones.

  • Any move below session lows (6,832) would point to downside continuation
  • A reversal above the 50 and 200-period MAs (~6,890) would lead to a quick test of 7,000

S&P 500 technical levels of interest:

Resistance Levels

  • 50 and 200 2H MAs (~6,890)
  • Previous ATH resistance 6,945 to 6,975 (testing)
  • Current ATH 7,020
  • All-time high resistance: 7,000 to 7,020 (range highs)

Support Levels

  • Session lows: 6,832
  • Current range intraday support: 6,820
  • Mini support 6,830 to 6,850
  • 6,800 psychological support
  • February lows 6,730 (higher timeframe range lows)
  • 6,400 major psychological support

Safe trades, and keep a close eye on the US-Iran developments & month-end flows!

Original Post

data.title: SM Energy: Debt Reduction Will Lead To A Significant Valuation Re-Rating
data.description:
Thesis

SM Energy (SM) released earnings after the market closed on Wednesday. The company reported strong progress on its synergy efforts less than one month following the close of its merger with Civitas Resources.

The market continues to underestimate the opportunity available through the SM improvement plan. SM is currently priced at a 14% free cash flow yield. This is before the company has had the opportunity to fully pursue synergy related cash flow improvements. This figure improves by several percentage points if the company is able to achieve the upper end of its synergy target.

In a first step toward this goal, SM announced it was selling a gassier block of its Eagle Ford acreage for a sale price of $950 million. This asset sale presents a modest impact to overall production values but significantly improves the company's balance sheet and interest expenses.

I expect the combination of deleveraging and free cash flow improvements to lead to significant share price appreciation. I am establishing a price target of $35 per share by year end 2027. This supports an annualized 25% return plus dividends to support a Strong Buy recommendation.

Earnings Release Highlights

On a standalone basis, SM executed well. The company generated $2.26B in full-year EBITDAX, valuing the base business at just 2.3 times full-year EBITDA. Additionally, the company paid down over $400 million in debt. In doing so, the company's leverage ratio was lowered to 1.05x, a very solid number.

Despite these achievements, the focus of the year-end earnings conference call was on 2026 guidance and the details surrounding the go-forward plan following the merger with Civitas Resources. At a high level, this plan focuses on maximizing free cash flow at the expense of some volumes. This will allow the company the financial flexibility to start paying down the heavy debt burden that was absorbed from Civitas.

More specifically, the company has slashed $450 million, or 14%, out of the 2025 CAPEX budget. The company will be dropping three rigs while focusing on oil-weighted locations. As a result, oil production is expected to climb modestly on a percentage basis. However, total production will be allowed to fall approximately 10%.

This decline in total production is somewhat inflated due to the previously announced sale of the company's gassier Eagle Ford assets. Excluding this transaction, forward production would have only reduced by 8% at the planned investment rate.

SM also provided an outline for future free cash flow deployment in 2026. The company announced a 10% dividend increase, bringing the company's yield up to 4%. The company also plans to continue to buy back shares, although this is expected to be the smallest aspect of the cash return framework.

The elephant in the room for this investment thesis is the company's goal to reduce debt. 80% of the free cash flow remaining after financing the dividend will be directed toward cleaning up the balance sheet. The size of this allocation corresponds directly to the scope of work that needs to be performed to complete repairs to the balance sheet.

With nearly $8B in total debt following the merger, SM's debt load currently dwarfs its own market cap ($5B). A strong effort to correct this issue is likely to result in an expanding multiple for the company that trades at industry low levels.

One of the key benefits of the merger with Civitas is that it allows SM to be on better terms with its lenders. The company has recently received two upgrades from Fitch and S&P Global, putting the company closer to achieving an investment-grade rating. Clearing this financial hurdle unlocks the opportunity for SM to trade at a significantly higher earnings multiple.

Synergy Progress And Upside Potential

At the onset of the merger, SM revealed a plan to generate $200-$300m in synergies. Roughly one month after the transaction closed, SM announced that action had been taken on $185 million of that target.

In the image below, we can see that G&A expense, as well as interest savings, represents the bulk of the improvements achieved to date. This amounts to much of the low hanging fruit from any merger of equals.

The CIVI C-suite has effectively been dismantled, leading to an easy G&A victory. Additionally, the company received a $950 million cash injection from divesting part of its Eagle Ford acreage. This debt can be used to tackle the inherited debt, some of which carries a 9.6% interest rate.

Operationally, the company has made initial strides in implementing efficiency improvements. However, it is far too early in the process to expect much progress in this area. As a result, only $60 million of the total $150 million opportunity set have embarked on any form of positive action.

Despite the progress, the market appeared dissatisfied as the company's share price traded down 4% after the earnings release. However, the SM story is one of synergies and balance sheet recovery. Both of these objectives require time and patience.

The market appears to be missing the two key facts. The first fact is that SM's free cash flow is growing through synergies. The already announced $185 million improvement in free cash flow represents a 3.5% improvement in FCF. That number expands to 6% if the full $300 million is realized.

The second fact that is being missed is that 100% of that free cash flow is being allocated for the benefit of shareholders. Dividends and buybacks are obvious ways to pay back shareholders. However, the balance sheet recovery story is something that is often overlooked.

Most investors steer away from highly levered companies. On a pro forma basis, the company holds a leverage ratio of approximately 1.5-1.7x, making it higher than what the market considers ideal. However, since SM remains highly cash flow positive, this problem is fixable.

In time, as SM repairs the balance sheet, leverage will be driven into the low 1.0 range per management commentary. These repairs allow SM to convert debt into shareholder equity and a higher share price. Further, as progress is achieved, the previously mentioned credit ratings can be improved.

The simple act of paying down debt creates a flywheel effect. Interest expenses reduce, unlocking more free cash flow. Better leverage then leads to an investment-grade rating and a higher multiple for the company’s stock. Better credit ratings allow the company to refinance its most expensive debt, again unlocking more free cash flow.

As shown below, SM trades at half the valuation level of its peers. Completing this process unlocks a significant re-rating that could allow the stock’s multiple to double over time.

Unfortunately, this process is long and slow. It requires consistent focus from the company to change the minds of the investment community. The next section will discuss why I have high confidence that SM can tackle this challenge.

Free Cash Flow Analysis

The 2026 operational plan for SM is to focus on value and not volumes. The company will allow total production activity to drop while focusing on higher oil concentration targets. As a result, the company's oil production has been guided to account for 54% of total volumes.

On the cost front, SM is guiding for a noticeable increase in lease operating expenses. This is likely derived from producing fewer barrels. The net result is a mid-single-digit increase in operating costs for the full year.

However, this is more than offset by the higher margins afforded by the higher oil cut. As a result, I now model SM to produce between $750 million and $850 million in 2026 FCF. This model was created using a $60/barrel and $2.55/MCF price deck, providing modest upside through the company's hedging portfolio.

These hedges cover roughly half of SM's projected volumes at attractive prices in excess of this model. As a result, these hedges conservatively protect the company’s current 14% FCF yield.

By adding in the company’s efforts on value creation, this figure is easily expandable. The company’s base case improvement is expected to realize $200 million in free cash flow uplift. This clearly pushes the optimized version of the company into the 20% FCF yield territory.

Risks

In recent weeks, oil has enjoyed a resurgence on the back of renewed tensions between the US and Iran. This political premium is unlikely to last forever and thus exposes the energy sector to near-term headwinds.

If this premium were to erode, the commodity would be forced to reconcile with an oversupplied market. While demand has remained resilient, supply is still dominating the market after OPEC+ fully ramped up production in mid-2025.

I do not expect the commodity to break out of the $60/barrel range, thus limiting SM’s margins. Even though the company has solid hedges in place, the market is unlikely to overlook the near-term challenge should there be a price reversion.

Investor Key Takeaways

1. SM Energy released its pro forma capital and production plans after the Civitas acquisition.

2. The company is targeting a significant CAPEX reduction as well as a higher concentration of oil production to improve margins.

3. I project SM as generating 14% in its current form. Cash flow improvements through synergies and optimizations hold the potential to boost this figure to over 20% in the long term.

4. This strong free cash flow will be allocated to debt reduction. By reducing the debt, shareholders should expect a valuation re-rating as the company pushes to achieve an investment-grade credit rating.

5. I hold a $35 price target due to this re-rating potential. This and the company’s 4% dividend yield are supportive of a Strong Buy recommendation.

data.title: Virtus Newfleet Multi-Sector Intermediate Bond Fund Q4 2025 Commentary
data.description:
Fixed Income Market Review

The fourth quarter of 2025 maintained the trend of significant shifts in macroeconomic, geopolitical, fundamental, and supply-demand dynamics seen in the third quarter. Markets continued to rebound from post-“Liberation Day” lows as legal challenges, implementation delays, and immediate economic impacts remained muted. While tariffs and other policy outcomes are still pending, we should see some resolution from the Supreme Court in the coming months. However, financial markets remained confident in a solid economy, rangebound inflation, and early signs of easing geopolitical risks.

U.S. economic data continued to signal resilience despite a U.S. government shutdown that delayed or cancelled key releases. Once resolved, the post-shutdown data confirmed that certain trends remained intact: positive growth, contained inflation, and unemployment that held near historically low levels despite some downside surprises. This allowed the Federal Reserve (Fed) to resume easing, cutting rates by 25 basis points (BPS) at both the October and December Federal Open Market Committee ('FOMC') meetings. The Fed has acknowledged that while elements of its mandate are in conflict, it has chosen to focus on protecting the labor market in the near term. Global monetary policy remains desynchronized, with divergences among the European Central Bank, Bank of England, and Bank of Japan. Geopolitical developments were mixed: volatility re-emerged in the Russia/Ukraine conflict, while the Middle East saw some signs of progress. China's military exercises late in the quarter around Taiwan were a reminder that tensions remain unresolved.

The ongoing market rebound drove broadly positive financial performance for 4Q. Fixed income sectors posted gains as front-end interest rates declined, and most spread sectors outperformed U.S. Treasuries. The U.S. Treasury curve steepened, with the 2-year yield down by 13 bps, the 5-year yield down by 2 bps, the 10-year yield up by 2 bps, and the 30-year yield higher by 11 bps.

Fund Performance Review

The Fund (Class I) returned 1.51% in the fourth quarter versus the Bloomberg U.S. Aggregate Bond Index return of 1.10%.

Positive Contributors

  • U.S. Treasury Securities: The Fund's underweight to U.S. Treasuries had a positive impact as most spread sectors outperformed U.S. Treasuries and delivered excess returns.
  • Emerging Markets ('EM') Sovereigns: Allocation and selection within EM sovereigns were positive.
  • Investment Grade ('IG') Corporates: The Fund's underweight and selection were positive.

Performance Detractors

  • Residential Mortgage-Backed Securities ('RMBS'): Allocation to RMBS over agency mortgage-backed securities ('MBS') was negative.
  • High Yield ('HY') Corporate Securities Selection: Selection versus the benchmark was negative.
  • Asset-Backed Securities ('ABS') Selection: Selection versus the benchmark was negative.

Current Fund Strategy and Positioning

  • Increased exposure to MBS, IG corporates, and cash.
  • Reduced exposure to ABS, RMBS, and bank loans.
  • In addition to changes to the Fund's sector allocation during the quarter, we continue to optimize positioning within sectors based on our view of the best relative value.

EM Debt and Non-U.S. Exposure: The J.P. Morgan EMBI Global Diversified Index ended 2025 on a strong note—its 3.29% return was supported by monetary easing, resilient technicals, and outperformance among select countries. High yield ('HY') credits led performance, while IG lagged amid modest spread volatility. Spreads tightened by 31 bps in 4Q to close the year at 253 bps. The J.P. Morgan CEMBI Global Diversified underperformed the J.P. Morgan EMBI Global Diversified, returning 1.29% amid significant volatility in Brazilian corporates during October. Local markets returned 3.34%, aided by a softer U.S. dollar and improving inflation. The Fund's overall EM exposure was marginally lower in 4Q. The Fund maintained a preference for U.S. dollar assets and EM HY over EM IG.

IG Corporates: IG corporate spreads widened 4 bps in 4Q to end 2025 in the high 70s, still at the very low end of the 20-year range. Yields were little changed at 4.81%. Supply was the big story as nearly $100 billion in issuance from large cloud providers set a new 4Q record. This caused some market indigestion even as demand drivers remained in place and flows stayed positive throughout the quarter. Credit metrics were stable while ratings drifted higher. BBBs are at their lowest percentage of the overall market in a decade. With valuations tight, we favor a defensive posture, with a preference for U.S. banks, utilities, and capital goods.

HY Corporates: The Bloomberg High Yield 2% Issuer Capped Bond Index gained 1.31% in 4Q. Credit spreads were little changed, with the Index ending 1 bp tighter at 266 bps. The market continues to focus on inflation and its impact on rates, the outlook for artificial intelligence and related spending, and consumer spending. Finance companies, metals & mining, and gaming outperformed during the quarter. Cyclical industries such as packaging, retailers, and buildings products lagged as lower-quality names declined sharply into year-end.

Securitized: The securitized markets posted positive total and excess returns in 4Q, outperforming other credit sectors. Spreads tightened despite elevated issuance across all securitized sub-sectors as investors sought additional income and spread. Our exposure to agency MBS outperformed IG corporates as strong technicals, the Fed rate cut, and low rate volatility rewarded investors. While our securitized strategy continues to focus on up-in-quality credits such as agency MBS, we're also selectively exploring transactions that present promising yield opportunities lower in the capital stack.

4Q 25 Virtus Newfleet Multi-Sector Intermediate Bond Fund (NAMFX)

Performance data quoted represents past performance. Past performance does not guarantee future results. Investment return and principal value will fluctuate so that shares, when redeemed, may be worth more or less than their original cost. Current performance may be lower or higher than the performance data quoted. Please visit Home Page for performance data current to the most recent month end. This share class has no sales charges and is not available to all investors. Other share classes have sales charges. See Home Page for details.

The fund class gross expense ratio is 0.80%. The net expense ratio is 0.74%, which reflects a contractual expense reimbursement in effect through 1/31/2026. Average annual total return is the annual compound return for the indicated period and reflects the change in share price and the reinvestment of all dividends and capital gains. Returns for periods of one year or less are cumulative returns.

Index: The Bloomberg U.S. Aggregate Bond Index measures the U.S. investment grade fixed rate bond market. The index is calculated on a total return basis. The index is unmanaged, its returns do not reflect any fees, expenses, or sales charges, and it is not available for direct investment.

The J.P. Morgan CEMBI Broad Diversified Index tracks total returns of U.S. dollar-denominated debt instruments issued by corporate entities in emerging market countries and consists of an investable universe of corporate bonds. The minimum amount outstanding required is $350 mm for the CEMBI Broad Diversified. The CEMBI Broad Diversified limits the weights of those index countries with larger corporate debt stocks by only including a specified portion of these countries' eligible current face amounts of debt outstanding. The J.P. Morgan EMBI Global Diversified Index (EMBI Global Diversified) tracks total returns for U.S. dollar-denominated debt instruments issued by emerging markets sovereign and quasi-sovereign entities: Brady bonds, loans, and Eurobonds. The index limits the weights of those index countries with larger debt stocks by only including specified portions of these countries' eligible current face amounts outstanding. The countries covered in the EMBI Global Diversified are identical to those covered by the EMBI Global. The index is calculated on a total return basis. The index is unmanaged, its returns do not reflect any fees, expenses, or sales charges, and is not available for direct investment. The Bloomberg U.S. High-Yield 2%

Issuer Capped Bond Index is a market capitalization-weighted index that measures fixed rate non-investment grade debt securities of U.S. and non-U.S. corporations. No single issuer accounts for more than 2% of market cap.

Newfleet Asset Management is a division of Virtus Fixed Income Advisers, LLC ("VFIA"), an SEC registered investment adviser.

Notes on Risk: Credit & Interest: Debt instruments are subject to various risks, including credit and interest rate risk. The issuer of a debt security may fail to make interest and/or principal payments. Values of debt instruments may rise or fall in response to changes in interest rates, and this risk may be enhanced with longer-term maturities. High Yield Fixed Income Securities (Junk Bonds): There is a greater risk of issuer default, less liquidity, and increased price volatility related to high yield securities than investment grade securities. Bank Loans: Bank loans may be unsecured or not fully collateralized, may be subject to restrictions on resale, may be less liquid and may trade infrequently on the secondary market. Bank loans settle on a delayed basis; thus, sale proceeds may not be available to meet redemptions for a substantial period of time after the sale of the loan. Foreign & Emerging Markets: Investing in foreign securities, especially in emerging markets, subjects the portfolio to additional risks such as increased volatility, currency fluctuations, less liquidity, and political, regulatory, economic, and market risk. ABS/MBS: Changes in interest rates can cause both extension and prepayment risks for asset- and mortgage-backed securities. These securities are also subject to risks associated with the non-repayment of underlying collateral, including losses to the portfolio. Market Volatility: The value of the securities in the portfolio may go up or down in response to the prospects of individual companies and/or general economic conditions. Local, regional, or global events such as war or military conflict, terrorism, pandemic, or recession could impact the portfolio, including hampering the ability of the portfolio's manager(s) to invest its assets as intended. Underlying Portfolio Data: Portfolio data shown includes indirect exposure through investments in other funds (if any) to the extent available and appropriate. Prospectus: For additional information on risks, please see the fund's prospectus.

The commentary is the opinion of the subadviser. This material has been prepared using sources of information generally believed to be reliable; however, its accuracy is not guaranteed. Opinions represented are subject to change and should not be considered investment advice or an offer of securities.

Please consider a Fund's investment objectives, risks, charges, and expenses carefully before investing. For this and other information about any Virtus Fund, contact your financial professional, call 800-243-4361, or visit Home Page for a prospectus or summary prospectus. Read it carefully before investing.

Not FDIC/NCUSIF Insured May Lose Value Not Bank Guaranteed

Editor's Note: This article covers one or more microcap stocks. Please be aware of the risks associated with these stocks.

data.title: FRDM: Are Emerging Market Equities Driving The U.S. Market?
data.description:
As the investing world scratches its collective head as to why the market (SP500) has been highly volatile but effectively flat since the start of the year and a consensus-thrashing Q4 by Nvidia (NVDA) led to a mid-single-digit decline, I'd like to showcase one specific ETF that seems to have captured ex-developed-market upside in a strong way and continues to do so.

The Freedom 100 Emerging Markets ETF (FRDM) is our dissection subject of the day. We're going to be looking at the fund itself, how it's built and for what purpose, and all that great stuff, but I think what's even more important is why the fund is behaving the way it is, and whether that's sustainable for the long haul. Let's get started.

The FRDM Fund for Top EM Equities

Just so you know where the fund's coming from, the "freedom" part refers to the portfolio strategy of weighting the equities using "personal and economic freedom metrics" as the basis for inclusion and allocation. Lady Liberty herself graces the ETF's webpage, and the fund seems to have distilled the level of protection provided to personal and economic freedom across 24 target EM countries and 87 individual metrics into a completely automated algorithm.

This "freedom-weighting" is then applied to rank the top ten companies in each of these EM countries, after which a market-cap weighting is applied on top. The result is a portfolio of about 120 equities ranked by their freedom weights and market caps.

The Life + Liberty Index acts as the benchmark, so this is a simple index fund but with specific criteria being used to compile the index and FRDM's portfolio.

The fund has an AUM of $2.97 billion as of February 26, with an expense ratio of 0.49%, or about average for the ETF universe. I'd have thought an automated portfolio that's little more than a fancy index fund would have much lower expenses, but that's not the case.

The fund has been around since May 2019, so there's plenty of data to work with in terms of how it's performed on a long-term horizon, give or take.

The country exposure figures are pretty interesting, but I'd like to explore the fund's core philosophies of "freedom-weighting", capturing freedom metrics at the country level, and a default exclusion of state-owned corporations (must be less than 20% state-owned to qualify for inclusion). These three philosophies seem to feed into the belief that "freedom makes better market", so let's look at some of the quant elements that comprise

So, the fund's underlying investment principle seems to be that the freer the market, the more efficiently capital and labor can be deployed, the more sustainable the growth, and the quicker the bouncebacks from economic downturns.

How Has This Investment Philosophy Translated to Performance?

We saw how the fund has performed on a YTD basis, but what about since inception? Since we have nearly 7 years of data, its price and total returns for the since-inception period are pretty meaningful. Let's see what's what.

FRDM clearly outperformed the market on all timelines, even when the U.S. market was flat, and that's what we've been seeing over the past couple of months.

Things look good historically, but that only means the fund has done its job of beating the market so far. What about in the future, which is our real goal here? To get to that, we'll need to check some of the top equities and see how they've been doing and whether or not their stocks still have steam to go higher.

Assessing the Top Equities of FRDM

Samsung Electronics (SSNLF), Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSM), and SK hynix (HXSC.F), the top three make up a little less than one-fourth of the portfolio, or about 24%, so looking at their performances in the last reported period and the outlook for the next should give us a pretty good view of where FRDM is headed in the near term.

Samsung reported earnings for Q4 and FY-25 in January, and it looks pretty good. Quarterly revenues and operating profits grew by an impressive 24%, while for the full year, revenues were up by 11%, EBITDA margin was up 2% to 26%, net margin grew to 14 basis points from 11 bps, and ROE was also up 2%, all on a YoY basis.

Business as usual, nothing to worry about here, but the biggest growth engine right now is Device Solutions, under which the Memory segment is reported. That's where we have the strongest evidence of growth, and we're going to see that with SK hynix as well.

The outlook for Memory is also very positive, with growth still on the table for Q1-26 as well as FY-26. The Foundry business is expected to see a seasonal decline in Q1-26 (sequential basis), but the full-year expectation is that advanced nodes are going to drive double-digit growth.

The seasonality theme seems to persist across other business segments like SDC (Samsung Display Corp.), where smartphone seasonal demand is expected to decline sequentially, and we could see some margin pressure from high-cost memory.

Other than the key issue of memory availability and pricing pressure, I don't see anything that points to a poor FY-26, so that's great for the ETF because it invests in the KRX listing (Korean Exchange), not the ADR. Trading volumes for the ADR are also pretty low, so if you're thinking of investing in this company, the Korean listing is likely the better option. If your brokerage doesn't provide that access, the FRDM ETF is the next best thing because it's able to capture capital appreciation pretty effectively.

Moving on to TSMC, the Taiwanese chipmaker also reported earnings in January, and the stock is already up over 13%. RSI isn't helping, and oscillators are indicating a neutral to bearish outlook, but key MAs show positive trends signaling a Buy, which is good for FRDM.

From a fundamentals standpoint, TSMC is rock-solid, with a forward revenue growth expectation of 30% against a 10% median figure, and an even better 35% GAAP EPS outlook. The best part is a lack of correlation to the broad U.S. market. You'd expect that because of the EM-only portfolio, but for the purpose of our FRDM analysis, that's a good sign.

As for SK hynix, the parent stock on the KRX is up 32% in the last month on the back of a 66% revenue bump in Q4, YoY. Memory is hot right now, and hynix is experiencing the full force of the AI infrastructure boom. This stock's got a ways to go, so no running out of steam in the near future for sure.

Freedom Works, But Only Outside the U.S.!

It's ironic that an EM-based freedom ETF would do much better than equities in the 'free-est' market of all, the U.S., but that's the current reality. FRDM has lots of room to appreciate, and it adds a nice layer of icing with the 1.8% yield. Not a lot, but that's mainly because of the underlying NAV appreciation more than anything.

Peak yield was around 5% at the end of 2023, and the dividend payouts are still a little lumpy, but it does add a thin layer of downside protection for investors.

I'd rate FRDM a Buy based on this analysis, and my higher-level view is that EMs have a lot to offer that the U.S. market doesn't right now, so this is a good time to take advantage of the growth differentials between EMs and developed markets.

Interestingly, it's companies like TSMC and hynix that are actually driving growth in U.S. markets, simply because of the fact that all the fastest-growing AI companies are buying products from them that nobody else is making at that scale and that level of advancement. Easy Buy for FRDM even if you only consider that one critical aspect.
